dublin_core.dcvalue: Growing interest surrounds the use ofinformation and communicationtechnologies ICTs for mental health related purposes yet little is known about rates of ICT use among the psychiatric population and those withsevere mental illness This study examinesICT accessibility among the psychiatric population focusing on serious and non serious mental illness SMI and non SMI Patients N 427 from all service branches of the Psychiatry Department at Emek Medical Centerwere recruited orally or through advertisement Responderscompleted a self report survey regarding accessibility and use of ICTs i e computer internet Facebook mobile phone smartphone Results revealed that 59 3 of respondents used computers 77 3 used the internet 92 7 owned a mobile phone 67 9 owned a smartphone and 63 used Facebook Over half of participants who used ICTs reported doing so at least once per day SMI and non SMI respondents differed significantly in their use and access to a computer the internet Facebook and smartphones Results suggest that mental illness is not a barrier to using and accessing technology however when differentiating between SMI and non SMI illness severity is a barrier to potential ICT utilization These results may encourage policymakers to design ICTs that suit the needs of individuals withSMI
